quoteFirst: The route, he saw, was to Bordeaux by the Paris-Orleans line, then on by the Midi to the Spanish frontier at Irun, and so by Medina and Salamanca to Oporto. The first through train from Paris after their arrival at 4.35 p.m. was the
quoteLast: from the Gare Quai d’Orsay, and this reached Oporto at shortly after midday on the next day but one, Monday. Oporto to Leixoes was only half an hour’s run, so he had six or seven hours’ margin. Oporto, he decided, was his goal.
title: Inspector French's greatest case
author: Crofts, Freeman Wills, 1879-1957

quoteFirst: By 10.15 A.M. the enemy was badly on fire and stopped. A few minutes later, at
quoteLast: , boats were observed to be leaving her and the _Alcantara_ ceased firing. The latter ship was by this time listing heavily and was abandoned shortly afterwards, sinking at 11.2 A.M. The _Andes_, which had been engaging the enemy at a longer range than the _Alcantara_, rendered assistance to the boats of the two ships.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: She stayed in her room writing. About ten o'clock she went out for a breath of air. She came back at
quoteLast: . How did she know the time? Because she stopped to set her watch by the clock in the hall. Afterwards she went straight to her room.
title: Convict B 14: A Novel
author: Weekes, R. K. (Rose Kirkpatrick), 1874-1956

quoteLast: Still, in the visi-screen, no other ship. Nothing but the giant planet, the smaller satellites poised against it, and the deep star-spangled curtain of black space all around.
title: The Affair of the Brains
author: Gilmore, Anthony
